Requirements: To apply, students must submit an online application (either the SUNY Application or the Common Application) and an official high school transcript. A letter of recommendation is optional but recommended. Test scores (SAT/ACT) are optional.
Description: Students completing the Accounting major are prepared for careers in public accounting (CPA firms), private accounting (business and not-for-profit organizations), and governmental accounting (local, state, and federal agencies). The program provides students with an understanding of financial accounting, managerial accounting, auditing, taxation, and accounting information systems. The curriculum, along with certain elective courses in other departments, also helps students meet the 150-hour education requirement for CPA licensure in New York State and other jurisdictions. Students typically pursue master's degrees to satisfy the 150-hour requirement. Students may also pursue Brockport's 4+1 BS/MS in Accounting program.

Requirements: Students who wish to minor in accounting must contact the department chair and file a 'Declaration of Minor' form in the Office of Academic Advisement. All students who wish to minor in accounting must complete the following courses with a minimum grade of C. Required Courses (6 credits): ACC 281 Principles of Financial Accounting; ACC 282 Principles of Managerial Accounting. Upper-Division Accounting Electives (12 credits).
Description: The Accounting minor provides non-business majors with foundational knowledge of financial and managerial accounting concepts. It helps students develop skills in analyzing, interpreting, and communicating financial information, which can be valuable in various professional fields. The minor may also serve as a stepping stone for students interested in pursuing an MBA or other graduate business programs.

Requirements: Prospective first-year students can apply using either the SUNY Application or the Common Application. Required application materials include the application and an official high school transcript. Other materials, such as letters of recommendation and a personal essay, are optional but strongly encouraged. SUNY Brockport is test-optional and does not require SAT or ACT scores for admission.
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Actuarial and Data Science at SUNY Brockport prepares students for careers in actuarial science and data science. The program includes a solid foundation in mathematics, statistics, computer science, and economics, along with practical skills in data analysis, modeling, and communication. Students will develop problem-solving skills, critical thinking, and ethical decision-making, while preparing to pass professional exams for actuarial science careers or pursue graduate studies in actuarial science, data science, or related fields.

The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) in Adapted Physical Education (APE) is designed to give students with a bachelor’s degree in Physical Education and/or Teaching Certification in Physical Education, the academic course work and field experiences to meet the New York State (NYS) requirements for teacher certification as an Adapted Physical Education teacher.

This 24-credit graduate certificate program may be completed in one year of full-time study or in two years of part-time study. Upon completion of the CAS in APE, candidates are eligible for initial/professional certification in APE through the NYS Education Department.

The CAS in APE at Brockport is offered as a stand-alone graduate certificate and as a concentration within the MS in Education (Physical Education or Health Education). Students interested in the MS in Education (Physical Education or Health Education) with a concentration in Adapted Physical Education will apply to the MS program and complete the 24-credits of APE coursework in addition to their core MS program requirements. Students in the CAS in APE are not required to complete a thesis or comprehensive exam.

Program Goals:
* To prepare future adapted physical education teachers with the knowledge and skills necessary to provide appropriate services to individuals with disabilities in physical education.
* To provide opportunities for candidates to demonstrate proficiency in the national adapted physical education standards.
* To provide opportunities for candidates to demonstrate proficiency in the NYS teaching standards for adapted physical education.
* To prepare candidates to meet the requirements for NYS teacher certification in adapted physical education.
* To provide candidates with opportunities to engage in applied research and scholarly activities.

Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: Brockport’s Addictions & Behavioral Health Major is a unique program dedicated to training the next generation of professionals to address the complex issues of addiction and mental health. This interdisciplinary degree prepares students to work in a variety of settings, including community agencies, hospitals, schools, and government organizations. You’ll learn to identify, prevent, and treat addiction and behavioral health issues through evidence-based practices, ethical considerations, and culturally sensitive approaches. Our curriculum emphasizes hands-on experience through internships and community engagement, ensuring graduates are well-prepared for immediate employment or further graduate studies in counseling, social work, public health, or related fields. Join us in making a difference in the lives of individuals, families, and communities affected by addiction and behavioral health challenges.

Requirements: This minor consists of 18 credits, 9 of which must be taken at SUNY Brockport. A grade of “C” or better must be earned in all minor courses.
Description: The Addictions and Behavioral Health Minor (non-clinical) at SUNY Brockport is designed for students interested in a variety of professions where knowledge about mental health and addiction is helpful but does not require direct clinical counseling. This minor is suitable for students pursuing careers in fields such as social work, public health, law enforcement, education, and human services, among others. Students will gain a strong foundation in understanding substance use disorders, behavioral addictions, mental health conditions, and co-occurring disorders. The curriculum covers topics such as assessment, prevention, treatment modalities, ethical considerations, and cultural competence, all from a non-clinical perspective. The minor prepares students to support individuals and communities affected by addiction and behavioral health challenges in roles that do not involve direct therapeutic intervention. This minor is not intended for students seeking to become licensed addiction counselors (CASAC).

Department: School of Arts and Sciences, School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: Our Adolescence Education: Biology (BS) program is designed for students who want to teach biology in grades 7-12. You'll gain a comprehensive understanding of biological concepts, including molecular biology, ecology, genetics, and evolution, while also developing the pedagogical skills necessary to effectively teach these subjects to adolescents. Our curriculum integrates theory with practical experience, providing opportunities for field experiences, lab work, and student teaching placements in local schools. Graduates of this program are prepared for New York State certification in Biology Grades 7-12.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Biology with Students with Disabilities Certification (BS)
Requirements: Freshman applicants must submit a completed application (SUNY Application or Common Application), an official high school transcript, a letter of recommendation, and a personal essay/statement. SUNY Brockport is test-optional, meaning students have the choice to submit SAT or ACT scores.
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: This program of study leads to initial/professional New York State certification in Adolescence Education: Biology (grades 7-12) and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12) Generalist. It is designed for students who are interested in teaching biology to adolescents, including those with disabilities, in public and private schools. The curriculum focuses on both the subject matter of biology and the pedagogical skills required to teach effectively across a range of student needs and abilities. It is a dual certification program.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP)

Requirements: To apply to SUNY Brockport as a first-year student, you will need: a completed application (SUNY Application or Common Application), an official high school transcript, and an essay or personal statement. SUNY Brockport is test-optional, so you can choose whether or not to submit SAT or ACT scores. One letter of recommendation from a teacher or school counselor is optional but highly encouraged.
Description: The undergraduate Adolescence Education: Chemistry (BS) degree provides content in Chemistry and professional education leading to New York State initial certification in Adolescence Education: Chemistry (grades 7-12). It is designed for students seeking to become secondary school teachers of chemistry. Graduates are prepared to use a variety of instructional strategies, technologies, and assessments to support diverse student learners in the chemistry classroom. This program also meets the academic requirements for a BS in Chemistry.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Chemistry with Students with Disabilities Certification (BS)
Requirements: Prospective students must submit a completed SUNY Application or Common Application, an official high school transcript, and an essay/personal statement. A letter of recommendation is optional but encouraged. Standardized test scores (SAT/ACT) are optional.
Department: School of Arts & Sciences and School of Education, Health & Human Services
Concentration: Chemistry with Students with Disabilities Certification
Description: This program prepares students to teach chemistry to adolescents (grades 7-12) and to instruct students with disabilities within a general education setting. Upon successful completion of the program, students are recommended for New York State Initial Certification in Adolescence Education: Chemistry and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12).

The Adolescence Education: Earth Science (BS) program prepares students to become highly effective middle school and high school Earth science teachers. This program is offered in collaboration with the Department of Earth Sciences, the Department of Education and Human Development, and the Professional Learning Community (PLC). Earth Science is a broad field of study covering many fascinating topics including astronomy, meteorology, oceanography, and geology.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Earth Science with Students with Disabilities Certification (BS)
Requirements: To apply as a first-year student, you’ll need to submit the following: a completed SUNY Application or Common Application, an official high school transcript, and a personal essay/statement. A letter of recommendation is optional but encouraged. SUNY Brockport is test-optional; SAT/ACT scores are not required for admission.
Department: School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Earth Science major provides students with a strong background in the physical and historical aspects of Earth sciences. In addition to a core curriculum of Earth Science courses, students choose from a variety of electives allowing them to customize their academic experience. Required courses include geology, meteorology, oceanography, astronomy, and environmental science. A strong emphasis is placed on field experiences. Completion of the Earth Science Adolescence Education BS degree fulfills the New York State academic requirements to be recommended for initial certification in Earth Science (grades 7-12) and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12).

Requirements: Admission to the College at Brockport does not guarantee admission to the teacher education program. To be eligible for admission to the adolescence inclusive generalist teacher certification program, students must have an overall Brockport GPA of 3.0 or higher. Students should declare their major in adolescence education and the content area as early as possible to receive appropriate advisement.
Description: The Adolescence Education: English program at SUNY Brockport prepares you to teach English (grades 7-12) in New York State public schools. This program combines a liberal arts education in English with professional coursework, field experiences, and student teaching. As a student in this program, you will develop a deep understanding of English language arts, including literature, writing, and language. You will also learn effective teaching strategies, classroom management techniques, and how to create an inclusive and equitable learning environment for all students. Our program emphasizes hands-on experience, with extensive opportunities for field placements in diverse school settings.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: English with Students with Disabilities Certification Program (BS)
Requirements: Students can apply using the SUNY Application or Common Application. We’ll need your official high school transcript(s) sent directly from your school. If you've taken any college-level coursework, we will need those official transcripts as well. A letter of recommendation and personal essay/statement are optional, but encouraged. SUNY Brockport is test-optional, which means you can choose whether or not to submit SAT or ACT scores as part of your application.
Description: This is an undergraduate dual certification program that leads to a Bachelor of Science (BS) degree in Adolescence Education: English (grades 7-12) with Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12). Upon successful completion of the program, students are recommended for New York State Initial Certification in Adolescence Education: English (grades 7-12) and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12). The program prepares students to teach English to adolescent learners, including those with disabilities. Courses focus on subject matter content, pedagogy, and professional skills required to meet the learning needs of all students in inclusive classrooms. Supervised field experiences, including student teaching, are integral components of the program. Admission into the teacher education program is required.
Accredidation: The Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP) accredits the programs leading to initial and advanced certification for teachers and school professionals at SUNY Brockport.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: History and Social Studies Major (BA / BS)
Description: The Adolescence Education: History and Social Studies Major (BA/BS) is a 46-credit program leading to an initial teaching certification in grades 7-12. The major is designed to provide students with a broad and deep understanding of history, government, economics, and geography, as well as the pedagogical skills necessary to teach these subjects effectively to adolescents. Students will engage in rigorous coursework that covers U.S. history, world history, and various social science disciplines. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, research, and analytical skills, preparing future educators to create dynamic and engaging learning environments. Field experiences and student teaching opportunities are integral components of the program, providing practical classroom experience.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: History and Social Studies with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BA / BS)
Requirements:
Admission to the University does not guarantee admission to the Adolescence Inclusive Generalist Education program. Students who meet the following requirements may apply for admission to the adolescence inclusive generalist teacher certification program:
1. Complete an application for admission to the teacher education program.
2. Have a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher.
3. Have completed the following courses with a grade of C or higher: EDI 431 Teaching & Learning in the Inclusive Classroom; PRO 370 Health & Drug Education for Teacher Candidates; One general education writing course.
4. Submit documentation of 50 clock hours of experience working with children or adolescents.
5. Submit a Disposition Form.
Department: School of Arts and Sciences and School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Adolescence Education: History and Social Studies with Students with Disabilities Certification major leads to New York state initial certification in both Adolescence Education: Social Studies (grades 7-12) and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12) generalist. This dual certification prepares students for careers as social studies teachers in middle and high schools, as well as special education teachers in grades 7-12. The program integrates content knowledge in history and social studies with pedagogical knowledge and skills in both general education and special education. Students complete a rigorous curriculum that includes coursework in history, political science, economics, geography, and sociology, as well as professional education courses focused on teaching methodologies, adolescent development, classroom management, and inclusive practices. Field experiences are embedded throughout the program, culminating in student teaching placements in both general education social studies and special education settings. Graduates are prepared to meet the diverse learning needs of all students in inclusive classrooms.
Accredidation: All of our teacher education programs at SUNY Brockport are registered by the New York State Education Department (NYSED) and nationally recognized by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

Department: School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: This program leads to a Bachelor of Science degree in Adolescence Education: Mathematics, and New York State initial certification to teach mathematics in grades 7-12. This program focuses on both the subject matter of mathematics and how to teach it effectively. Graduates will be prepared to teach a wide range of mathematics courses, from pre-algebra through calculus and statistics, in middle and high school settings. Through a blend of rigorous coursework in mathematics, education theory, and extensive field experiences, students develop the pedagogical skills and subject matter expertise necessary for a successful teaching career. The curriculum is designed to meet the academic and professional standards set forth by the New York State Education Department for teacher certification. This program also provides a strong foundation for students who may wish to pursue graduate studies in mathematics education or a related field.
Accredidation: Meets the academic and professional standards set forth by the New York State Education Department for teacher certification, and leads to New York State initial certification to teach mathematics in grades 7-12.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Mathematics with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS)
Department: School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Adolescence Education: Mathematics with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS) prepares students for certification to teach mathematics at the secondary level (grades 7-12) and provides initial certification in Students with Disabilities Generalist (grades 7-12). Our program provides you with a strong foundation in both mathematics and education, ensuring you have the knowledge and skills necessary to be an effective teacher for all students. Upon completion of the program, students will be qualified to teach mathematics in traditional classroom settings and to work with students with disabilities in inclusive settings, resource rooms, and consultant teacher roles. You will be prepared for a rewarding career helping young people succeed.

Department: School of Arts and Sciences, School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: This program prepares students to teach physics in grades 7-12 in New York State public schools. Upon successful completion of the requirements, graduates are eligible for initial certification in New York State. Students are prepared to be highly competent teachers with strong content knowledge in physics and extensive experience in pedagogical techniques. The coursework for the major also prepares students for advanced graduate work in physics, science education, and related fields. In addition to courses in the natural sciences, mathematics, and education, the program requires an intensive student teaching experience. Students who have successfully completed the program are prepared to teach physics and general science courses at the middle and high school level. A minor in Mathematics is also required. Students will be advised by faculty in both the Department of Physics and the Department of Education and Human Development.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $2,500 per year for freshmen

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Physics with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS)
Description: The Adolescence Education: Physics with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS) prepares students to teach physics and earth science (grades 7-12) to all students, including those with disabilities. Students are required to complete a dual major, consisting of Physics (BS) and Adolescence Education (BS). The Physics component provides a deep understanding of the subject matter, including classical mechanics, electromagnetism, thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, and optics. The Adolescence Education component focuses on pedagogical strategies, classroom management, curriculum development, and student assessment, with a particular emphasis on inclusive practices for students with disabilities. Graduates are eligible for initial certification in New York State as a teacher of Physics and Earth Science (grades 7-12) and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12).

Requirements:
Students intending to major in Adolescence Spanish Education should declare the major as early as possible, usually upon completion of the language prerequisite of SPN 212. To be admitted to the major, students must meet the following requirements:

1. Completion of a minimum of 36 college credits.
2. A minimum cumulative Brockport GPA of 2.5.
3. Completion of SPN 350 and SPN 351 with a minimum grade of "C."
4. Completion of ENL 112 with a minimum grade of "C."
5. A minimum content area GPA of 2.75 in all required Spanish coursework taken to date.
Department: School of Arts and Sciences and School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Adolescence Education: Spanish, BS, prepares students to teach Spanish to students in grades 7-12. This program combines a liberal arts education, a thorough understanding of Spanish language and culture, and professional preparation in teaching methods and educational psychology. Upon successful completion of all program requirements, including passing required New York State Teacher Certification Examinations, students are recommended for New York State Initial Certification in Adolescence Education: Spanish (grades 7-12). This program leads to teacher certification in New York State. Graduates are eligible to pursue positions as Spanish teachers in middle schools and high schools across New York State.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Spanish with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS)
Department: School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Adolescence Education: Spanish with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS) prepares students for certification in teaching Spanish in grades 7-12, as well as students with disabilities in general education settings in grades 7-12. This program combines two certification areas and allows candidates to meet all New York State requirements for initial and professional certification. The major provides students with content in Spanish, general pedagogical knowledge, and pedagogy specifically designed for Spanish instruction and for students with disabilities.

ProgramName: African and African-American Studies Major (BA, BS)
Description: The African and African-American Studies Major is an interdisciplinary program designed to examine the historical, cultural, economic, political, and social conditions of people of African descent. Students will analyze the dynamics of these factors and develop a comprehensive understanding of the African and African-American experience. The program aims to foster critical thinking, analytical skills, and a global perspective. Upon completion, students will be prepared for a variety of careers in fields such as education, social work, public policy, community development, and international relations, or for further graduate study.

Requirements: To declare a minor in African and African-American Studies, contact the department chair.
Description: The African and African American Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a critical understanding of the experiences, cultures, and contributions of people of African descent. Students will analyze the historical, social, political, economic, and cultural forces that have shaped African and African American societies, both globally and locally. The minor will enhance students' abilities to engage in critical thinking, research, and effective communication about complex issues of race, identity, power, and social justice. This program prepares students to become globally aware, socially responsible citizens who can contribute to a more just and equitable world.

Aging is a multidisciplinary, global, and individual human experience. The Aging Studies Interdisciplinary Minor provides an opportunity to develop an understanding of the aging process through multiple perspectives, including health, psychology, sociology, politics, economics, history, and the arts. Courses are designed to introduce students to current topics in aging and to prepare them for careers in the growing field of gerontology. The minor complements many majors, including but not limited to, nursing, social work, public health, psychology, sociology, healthcare administration, and recreation. Students completing the minor will also be prepared for graduate study in gerontology and related fields. The minor may be completed online or on campus.

Requirements: Applicants must submit a completed application using either the SUNY Application or the Common Application, along with an official high school transcript. Standardized test scores (SAT/ACT), a letter of recommendation, and an essay/personal statement are optional and not required for a complete application.
Description: Anthropology is the scientific and humanistic study of humanity across time and space. As a holistic discipline, anthropology focuses on the interrelationships of human biology, language, culture, and society. The anthropology major at SUNY Brockport provides students with a broad and balanced understanding of the four subfields of anthropology (archaeology, biological anthropology, linguistic anthropology, and sociocultural anthropology) and the unique theoretical and methodological approaches each subfield brings to the study of humanity. Students will be provided with opportunities for hands-on learning in the classroom and through participation in community-based research, ethnographic field schools, archaeological excavations, study abroad, and internship experiences. The program offers students the option to pursue either a BA or BS degree depending on their career interests.

The Art History minor at SUNY Brockport offers students an opportunity to study art in its historical, social, and cultural contexts. Students explore art from antiquity to the present and gain an understanding of various movements, styles, and themes across different cultures and time periods. The minor provides a foundation in visual analysis and critical thinking, encouraging students to interpret and articulate their understanding of artworks. It complements a wide range of majors by enhancing students’ cultural literacy and global awareness, making it an excellent choice for those interested in careers in museums, galleries, education, conservation, or further graduate study in art history.

Concentration: Graphic Design, Illustration, New Media, Painting and Drawing, Photography, Printmaking, Sculpture, Ceramics, Art Education, Museum Studies
Description:
The Department of Art at SUNY Brockport offers Bachelor of Arts (BA), Bachelor of Science (BS), and Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) degrees in Art. This page focuses on the BA and BS degrees.
The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Art offers students a broad liberal arts education with a strong foundation in art. Students develop a comprehensive understanding of art history, theory, and practice, while also exploring various studio disciplines. The BA program emphasizes critical thinking, research, and communication skills, preparing students for diverse career paths or further graduate studies in fields such as art history, museum studies, arts administration, or art criticism.
The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Art is designed to prepare students for a career in art-related fields such as graphic design, illustration, museum studies, and art education. Students choose a concentration within the BS program. The BS program combines a strong foundation in art with focused study in a specific area, providing students with the technical skills and theoretical knowledge necessary for professional practice. Graduates of the BS program are well-prepared for entry-level positions in their chosen field or for further specialized training.

Requirements: Admission into the BFA program is by application and portfolio review only. Students who have completed the foundations coursework (or who are concurrently enrolled in the remaining foundations courses) and who have an overall GPA of 2.5 and a GPA of 3.0 in Art are eligible to apply. The application requires a portfolio of 12-15 images, an artist statement of 300 words, an unofficial transcript, and two letters of recommendation from faculty.
Description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) degree is the professional undergraduate degree in the visual arts. It is designed for students seeking an intensive study of the visual arts within the context of a liberal arts education. Students develop high-level skills, critical thinking, and an understanding of contemporary art theory and practice as they pursue advanced work in a selected area of studio art. The program provides the knowledge and experience necessary to pursue a professional career in art or to continue their education in graduate school.

Requirements:
A minimum of 18 credits in studio art is required for the minor. Nine credits must be taken in residence at SUNY Brockport. A grade of C or higher is required in all courses for the minor. The student and the minor coordinator will design a coherent program to fit the student’s interests and goals.

Required Courses (9 credits)
ARS 211 Drawing I (3 credits)
ARS 221 Two-Dimensional Design (3 credits)
ARS 231 Three-Dimensional Design (3 credits)

Electives (9 credits)
Choose 9 credits from ARS courses at the 300/400 level.
Description: The Art - Studio Minor is intended for students who wish to pursue an area of studio art in depth without committing to a full major. Students choose a primary medium or approach in which to develop studio skills and concepts. The courses selected for this minor provide students with a solid foundation in the visual arts while allowing the flexibility to pursue individual interests. Students will take foundational courses and then advanced studio courses in their chosen area.

The biochemistry major is designed to provide students with a strong background in chemistry and biology, with an emphasis on the intersection of these two disciplines. Biochemists investigate the chemical processes within and relating to living organisms. The rigorous curriculum prepares students for graduate study in biochemistry and related fields (e.g., cell biology, molecular biology, biophysics), health professions (medical, dental, pharmacy), or entry-level positions as technicians in the chemical and pharmaceutical industries, biotechnology, environmental science, and forensics laboratories.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, from $1,000 to full in-state tuition per year

Requirements: To apply, applicants must submit a completed application (either the SUNY Application or the Common Application) and an official high school transcript. SAT/ACT scores and one letter of recommendation are optional for freshman applicants. An essay is strongly encouraged.
Concentration: Environmental Science, Pre-Medical, Biotechnology, Aquatic Biology, Ecology, Neuroscience
Description: The Biology program provides a strong foundation in the biological sciences. The program emphasizes both theoretical and practical applications of biology. Students learn about the fundamental principles of life, from molecular and cellular processes to ecosystems and evolution. Through a combination of coursework, laboratory experiences, and research opportunities, students develop critical thinking skills, scientific literacy, and a comprehensive understanding of biological systems. The program prepares students for a wide range of careers in biology, health professions, environmental science, biotechnology, and education, as well as for graduate studies.
ScholarshipAmount: Ranges from $1,500 to $9,500 annually depending on the scholarship.

Requirements: Students wishing to declare a minor in biology must fill out the 'Undergraduate Program Declaration Form' online. Must be in good academic standing (GPA 2.0 or higher).
Description: Are you considering a minor in biology? We offer an undergraduate minor that provides a comprehensive overview of the field and complements a variety of majors. Students gain foundational knowledge in biological concepts, including cell biology, genetics, ecology, and evolution, and develop critical thinking and laboratory skills relevant to scientific inquiry. With a biology minor, you'll enhance your resume and broaden your understanding of the natural world, preparing you for diverse career paths or further studies in health professions, environmental science, and more.

The Broadcast Meteorology minor is a course of study designed to provide students with the foundational academic coursework in meteorology while also providing experience in the communication, graphic presentation, and forecasting skills necessary to communicate meteorology to the public via broadcast and digital media. This minor is open to all students at SUNY Brockport.

The Business Administration program offers you a broad understanding of the functional areas of business and provides an opportunity to develop analytical and problem-solving skills necessary to succeed in a dynamic business environment. The program prepares you for a wide variety of careers in business, government, and not-for-profit organizations. It also provides an excellent foundation for graduate study in business or law. Students pursuing the Business Administration BS can pursue a general Business Administration curriculum or choose to pursue a specialization from the following list: Business Economics (BBE), Finance (BFI), International Business (BIB), Marketing (BMK), Organizational Management (BOM), Sport Management (BSM), Supply Chain Management (BSCM), or Undeclared (UND). Students may choose a specialization or remain undeclared in the program. Each specialization focuses on a specific business area. In addition to choosing a specialization, Business Administration majors can participate in a variety of clubs and organizations, join the international honor society Beta Gamma Sigma, complete an internship, and study abroad.
Accredidation: The School of Business and Management at SUNY Brockport is accredited by AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.

ProgramName: Business Administration Online Degree Completion Program (BS)
Requirements:
To be admitted to the program, a student must have:
- Completed a minimum of 24 college credits
- Achieved a cumulative GPA of 2.5 or higher
- Completed the following four prerequisite courses with a C or better:
    - Financial Accounting
    - Managerial Accounting
    - Microeconomics
    - Statistics
Department: School of Business, Public Administration, and Economics
Description: The Business Administration Online Degree Completion program (BS) at SUNY Brockport is designed for students who have already earned an associate degree or have significant college credit, and wish to complete their bachelor’s degree in a flexible online format. Our program prepares you for a wide range of careers in various industries, providing you with a strong foundation in business principles and practices. This program is ideal for transfer students with an Associate in Science (AS) degree in Business Administration, or those who have completed 60 or more college credits. Students will be able to transfer most of their previously earned credits, allowing them to complete their degree efficiently. Our curriculum covers essential business areas such as accounting, finance, marketing, management, and business law, equipping you with the knowledge and skills necessary to succeed in today's competitive business environment. You'll gain practical experience through case studies, projects, and simulations, preparing you for leadership roles and advanced studies.

A minor in Business provides students from any major across the College with a foundational understanding of business principles and practices essential for success in today's dynamic global economy. The curriculum is designed to offer a broad overview of key business functions, including management, marketing, finance, and economics. Students will develop critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills applicable to various professional settings. This minor enhances a student’s primary field of study by providing them with a competitive edge and preparing them for diverse career opportunities or further graduate studies in business-related fields.

Requirements: To be considered for admission to the Chemistry major, you must meet the general admission requirements for SUNY Brockport. First-year students must submit an application (either the SUNY Application or the Common Application) and an official high school transcript. Letters of recommendation and SAT/ACT scores are optional.
Description:
As a Brockport chemistry major, you will study atoms, molecules, and chemical reactions and develop critical thinking skills through research. You will receive extensive classroom and laboratory training in a diverse range of areas including analytical, biochemistry, inorganic, organic, and physical chemistry. You will apply knowledge to solve important real-world problems. With a rigorous curriculum, the BS in Chemistry is designed for students interested in careers in scientific research and development, forensic science, and medicine, as well as graduate study in chemistry or related disciplines. Our program is approved by the American Chemical Society (ACS).

Upon completion of the chemistry major, students will be able to demonstrate: Knowledge and understanding of chemical principles in the five major sub-disciplines: analytical, biochemistry, inorganic, organic, and physical chemistry. Ability to critically evaluate chemical information and apply the scientific method to solve chemical problems. Proficiency in the safe and proper handling of chemicals and operation of instrumentation. Clear and concise communication of chemical information through oral and written formats. Ability to work effectively and collaboratively in a professional setting. Understanding of the ethical responsibilities of chemical professionals and impact of chemistry on society. The Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry provides students with a high quality, student-centered education that prepares them for success in industry, education, graduate school, or professional programs. We offer several opportunities for students to obtain hands-on research experience with faculty mentors using modern instrumentation, and encourage students to present their work at local, regional, and national conferences. We also foster a strong sense of community, through a supportive and friendly environment, and sponsor a local chapter of the American Chemical Society student organization, providing opportunities for professional development and outreach activities.
Accredidation: Approved by the American Chemical Society (ACS)

ProgramName: Chemistry Major with ACS Certification (BA, BS)
Requirements: To be considered for admission, applicants must submit a completed application (SUNY Application or Common Application) and official high school transcript(s). Letters of recommendation and a personal essay are optional but strongly encouraged. SUNY Brockport is a test-optional institution, so SAT/ACT scores are not required for admission. Admission to the major itself requires students to earn a grade of C or higher in CHM 205 and CHM 206 and obtain permission from the department after enrolling at the university.
Description:
The Bachelor of Arts (BA) or Bachelor of Science (BS) in Chemistry with Certification by the American Chemical Society (ACS) is a comprehensive program for students interested in a rigorous chemistry education. It is designed for students seeking careers in industrial chemistry, government laboratories, graduate school in chemistry or a related field, or professional programs such as medicine or dentistry.

Upon completion of this program, students will be able to:
*   Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental principles of inorganic, organic, analytical, physical, and biochemistry.
*   Perform a variety of laboratory techniques safely and proficiently.
*   Interpret and analyze experimental data, and effectively communicate scientific results orally and in writing.
*   Apply critical thinking and problem-solving skills to chemical challenges.
*   Understand ethical responsibilities in the practice of chemistry.
Accredidation: Certified by the American Chemical Society (ACS)

Department: School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Childhood Inclusive Education (B.S.) program leads to New York State teacher certification in Childhood Education (Grades 1-6) and Students with Disabilities (Grades 1-6). This dual certification prepares teacher candidates to work with students across the full spectrum of abilities and learning needs within inclusive general education classrooms, as well as in special education settings. The program also leads to certification in Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL PreK-12).

Climate change is a global issue that requires an interdisciplinary approach to understand and address its complex impacts. The Climate Studies Major (BS) provides students with a strong scientific foundation in the physical processes that govern Earth’s climate system, as well as an understanding of the societal, economic, and political dimensions of climate change. Students will develop critical thinking skills, data analysis techniques, and communication abilities necessary to become effective climate professionals. The program emphasizes hands-on research experiences and opportunities for internships with government agencies, non-profit organizations, and private industry. Upon completion of the Climate Studies Major (BS), students will be able to: Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of Earth’s climate system, including its components, processes, and drivers of change. Analyze and interpret climate data using appropriate scientific methods and tools. Evaluate the societal, economic, and political impacts of climate change. Communicate complex climate science concepts effectively to diverse audiences. Apply interdisciplinary approaches to address climate-related challenges.

Requirements: Students intending to complete this minor must meet with an advisor in the Department of Kinesiology, Sport Studies and Physical Education to declare the minor and plan a course of study.
Description: The minor in coaching offers students an opportunity to learn about the various aspects of coaching. This minor provides a foundation in physical fitness, nutrition, and psychological and physiological principles of training. It is designed to prepare students to be successful coaches at various levels.

Requirements: To apply for freshman admission, please submit the following: Completed application (SUNY Application or Common Application); Official high school transcript(s); Official college transcript(s), if applicable. SUNY Brockport is test-optional for undergraduate applicants.
Description: The Communication Studies major is a broadly-based program of study designed for students interested in developing the knowledge, skills, and values required for effective communication in a variety of personal and professional settings. It provides students with a general understanding of communication processes and their relationship to human behavior and social organization. Students learn to critically analyze the effects of communication on various publics and to produce and disseminate messages through traditional and emerging communication technologies. The program focuses on critical thinking, research, problem solving, ethics, and civic engagement. Graduates are prepared for careers in fields such as public relations, advertising, marketing, human resources, journalism, broadcasting, government, and non-profit organizations. It also provides an excellent foundation for graduate study in communication or a related field.

A minor in Communication Studies provides students with a foundational understanding of the communication process. This program will enhance a student’s ability to analyze, critique, and create messages for various audiences and contexts. By studying communication, students will develop critical thinking skills, improve their oral and written communication, and gain insight into human interaction within diverse settings. This minor complements many majors by providing valuable communication skills applicable to a wide range of careers.

Requirements: To apply for first-year admission, please submit the following materials: A completed application (you can use the SUNY Application or the Common Application), Your official high school transcript, One letter of recommendation (optional but strongly recommended), An essay (optional but strongly recommended). SUNY Brockport is test-optional. You can choose whether to submit SAT/ACT scores.
Description: The Community Justice Major provides students with a broad and deep understanding of the causes and consequences of injustice, as well as the historical and contemporary responses to it. Students learn about the role of the criminal legal system as it relates to issues of social, political, and economic injustice, as well as the ways in which communities have worked to address harm and promote well-being outside of traditional state systems. Students are encouraged to develop a critical lens through which they will examine issues of justice within varied contexts including race, class, gender, and geography. The major emphasizes critical thinking, research, and communication skills, preparing students for careers in fields such as social justice advocacy, restorative justice, community organizing, victim services, and policy analysis, as well as graduate studies in law, public policy, social work, and other related fields.

Requirements: In addition to meeting the general College admission requirements, students wishing to major in computer information systems are expected to have completed four units of high school mathematics.
Description: Our Bachelor of Science in Computer Information Systems (CIS) is designed to provide you with the necessary tools to become a valuable asset in the modern business world. You’ll be prepared for careers as an analyst, designer, implementer, or manager of information systems in organizations. The program focuses on both the technical and business aspects of information systems. You’ll develop a strong foundation in computer programming, database management, network administration, cybersecurity, and project management, while also gaining a comprehensive understanding of business principles and practices. Our curriculum is regularly updated to reflect the latest industry trends and technologies, ensuring that you graduate with relevant and in-demand skills. You’ll also have opportunities to engage in hands-on projects, internships, and research, providing you with practical experience and networking opportunities.

Requirements: A grade of C or higher is required in all courses for the minor. The CIS minor is not available to majors in computer science or computer information systems.
Description: The Computer Information Systems minor provides students with a foundational understanding of information systems, programming, database management, and networking. This minor is an excellent complement to many majors, enhancing a student's technical skills and problem-solving abilities within various fields.

With a Computer Science bachelor's degree from SUNY Brockport, you'll develop the problem-solving skills needed to succeed in an ever-growing field. Graduates will learn to design, build, and implement software. The Computer Science (BS) program prepares students for a career as a software developer, IT consultant, data analyst, or for graduate study. This program will also help prepare students for certifications.

The Computer Science minor offers students an opportunity to supplement their major area of study with foundational computer science knowledge and skills. The minor emphasizes problem-solving techniques and algorithmic thinking relevant to many fields of study. Students will gain experience in programming, data structures, and the theoretical underpinnings of computation. This minor is particularly valuable for students pursuing careers that increasingly rely on technological proficiency, or for those considering graduate studies in interdisciplinary fields involving computation.

Are you interested in a career fighting crime or helping people navigate the justice system? A Criminal Justice major at SUNY Brockport prepares you for a rewarding career in law enforcement, courts, corrections, juvenile justice, and more. You’ll gain practical and theoretical knowledge through hands-on learning, internships, and research opportunities. Our comprehensive curriculum covers criminal behavior, law enforcement, judicial processes, correctional systems, and social justice issues.

Students in the Criminal Justice minor gain a fundamental understanding of the criminal justice system in the United States. The program offers courses in policing, corrections, courts, and crime prevention, providing a solid foundation for careers in law enforcement, corrections, and legal fields. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, ethical considerations, and a commitment to social justice within the criminal justice context. This minor is an excellent complement to majors in sociology, psychology, political science, and social work.
ScholarshipAmount: $1,000 - $5,000 per year, up to full in-state tuition

ProgramName: Criminal Justice Online Degree Completion Program (BS)
Description: The Criminal Justice Online Degree Completion Program provides students who have earned an associate’s degree from a regionally accredited institution with the opportunity to complete their bachelor's degree online. Students who complete this program will earn a Bachelor of Science (BS) in Criminal Justice. The online degree completion program provides a high-quality education in the field of criminal justice within the flexibility of an online format. The program provides the foundational knowledge, theoretical insights, and methodological skills necessary for students to pursue careers in a variety of criminal justice fields or to pursue graduate study.

Requirements:
To apply for first-year admission, you’ll need:

- Completed application (SUNY Application or Common Application)
- Official high school transcript
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Cybersecurity at SUNY Brockport prepares students for a career in cybersecurity. Students will learn how to design, implement, and maintain secure computer systems, networks, and software. They will also learn how to identify, analyze, and respond to cyber threats. The program emphasizes both theoretical and practical aspects of cybersecurity, including cryptography, network security, ethical hacking, and digital forensics. Graduates will be equipped with the knowledge and skills necessary to protect organizations from cyberattacks and ensure the privacy and integrity of data.

Requirements: To declare this minor, students must have a cumulative GPA of 2.0 or higher.
Description: This interdisciplinary minor provides students with the fundamental knowledge and skills needed to understand the cybersecurity landscape. Students learn about network security, cryptography, digital forensics, ethical hacking, and cybersecurity best practices. This minor is suitable for students in a wide range of majors, including computer science, information technology, criminal justice, and business. It complements any major by providing essential skills for protecting digital assets in an increasingly interconnected world.

Dance at Brockport provides students with comprehensive training in contemporary dance techniques, ballet, choreography, improvisation, dance history, dance performance, somatics, and production. The curriculum is designed to develop students’ artistic and intellectual potential through an emphasis on both theoretical and practical applications of dance. Students learn how to apply knowledge in a variety of settings, including performance, choreography, research, and teaching. Our faculty are active artists, scholars, and educators who bring a wealth of professional experience to the classroom and studio. The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Dance allows students to combine their passion for dance with a minor or second major in another field. The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Dance prepares students for graduate study in performance, choreography, dance education or dance science related fields. Students may also pursue a minor or second major.

Requirements: Admission to the BFA program is by audition. Students may audition prior to admission to the University, or during their first two semesters of study. The audition consists of a master class including contemporary modern and ballet techniques, as well as a short interview with the faculty. Applicants should bring a résumé of dance experience and a small photo to the audition. In addition to the audition, applicants must meet the general undergraduate admission requirements, which include submitting either the SUNY Application or the Common Application and an official high school transcript.
Description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts degree with a major in Dance offers an intensive, professional course of study in the art and craft of dance performance and choreography in the context of a liberal arts education. It provides a comprehensive approach to the study of dance technique, choreography, performance, dance history, movement analysis and theory. The BFA program prepares students to pursue careers as performers, choreographers, and educators, and provides a strong foundation for graduate study. This professional degree is considered the first professional degree in the field of dance. In order to enroll in the dance major, all students must audition for acceptance into the program (audition information is available from the Department of Dance).

Department: School of Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences
Description: A minor in Dance offers students the opportunity to augment their studies with dance coursework. The Dance minor is comprised of 18 credits from required courses and dance electives. Students can explore technique, theory, and creative practice in the field of dance. The coursework includes opportunities for students to study current and historical dance forms, create original choreography, and gain performance experience. A dance minor can complement a wide variety of majors, including arts management, theatre, education, exercise science, and business. It can also prepare students for graduate studies in dance or careers in dance-related fields.
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $1,000 per year to full in-state tuition.

Description: Digital Marketing helps organizations connect with target audiences across digital channels to achieve strategic objectives. In the Digital Marketing minor, students will learn to develop, implement, and analyze digital marketing strategies through topics such as social media marketing, search engine optimization, email marketing, content marketing, and digital advertising. This minor complements a variety of majors by providing students with foundational knowledge and skills applicable in today's digital economy.
Accredidation: The Department of Business Administration is proud to hold AACSB Accreditation. AACSB International (The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business) accreditation represents the highest standard of achievement for business schools worldwide. Less than five percent of the world's 16,000 business programs have earned AACSB accreditation.

Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: The Disability Studies minor at SUNY Brockport prepares students to understand and critically analyze disability as a social, cultural, and political phenomenon. It exposes students to diverse perspectives on disability, including those of disabled people, and encourages them to challenge conventional assumptions about disability and normalcy. Students completing the minor will have a strong foundation in disability theory, history, and policy, and will be able to apply this knowledge to a variety of professional and academic contexts. The minor is highly interdisciplinary, drawing on insights from fields such as sociology, psychology, history, literature, communication, and education. It is designed to complement a wide range of majors, including those in the humanities, social sciences, health sciences, and education.

ProgramName: Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Social Justice Minor
Description: The Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Social Justice (DEISJ) Minor at SUNY Brockport emphasizes theoretical and applied understandings of diversity, equity, inclusion, and social justice. Students develop the skills to think critically about issues of power, privilege, and oppression and apply their learning to foster equitable and just communities. This interdisciplinary minor enables students to engage with multiple perspectives on diversity, equity, inclusion, and social justice and how these issues intersect within various social contexts. Through an interdisciplinary curriculum, students engage in critical analysis and reflective practices to address systemic inequalities, advocate for marginalized communities, and promote a culture of inclusivity and social responsibility. The minor culminates in a capstone experience where students integrate their knowledge and skills in a practical project related to DEISJ issues.

Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: The Early Childhood Inclusive Education (BS) program prepares students to meet the diverse learning and developmental needs of young children (birth-grade 2) in various inclusive settings. This program is designed to provide students with the knowledge, skills, and dispositions necessary to become effective educators who can create supportive and engaging learning environments for all children, including those with disabilities. Graduates of this program will be eligible for New York State certification in Early Childhood Education (birth-grade 2) and Students with Disabilities (birth-grade 2).
Accredidation: Teacher Education programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

Requirements: To apply for undergraduate admission, students must submit a completed SUNY Application or Common Application, an official high school transcript, one letter of recommendation, and an application essay or personal statement. SUNY Brockport is test-optional, meaning SAT/ACT scores are not required for admission.
Concentration: Geology Concentration, Earth Science Teacher Certification Concentration
Description:
Earth science is the study of the Earth, its materials, and the processes that affect them. Earth science examines the formation, evolution and behavior of the physical world around us. Earth scientists use the tools of physics, chemistry, and biology to study both the natural processes and how human activity impacts them.
The Earth Science Program provides students with a broad and rigorous background in the natural sciences, with an emphasis on understanding the Earth’s systems. The curriculum offers opportunities for students to explore topics such as geology, meteorology, oceanography, hydrology, and environmental science. Students will develop critical thinking skills, problem-solving abilities, and field experience essential for careers in earth science or for graduate studies.

Requirements: To earn a minor in earth science, a student must complete a minimum of 18 credits in earth science courses (ESCI), including at least nine credits at the 300/400 level, with a minimum grade of C- in each course and a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0 in the minor.
Description: The Earth Science minor provides students with the fundamental knowledge and skills needed to understand the various processes that operate on, within, and above the Earth. Students learn about how our Earth operates and how the various components (solid Earth, atmosphere, oceans, cryosphere, and biosphere) interact with each other and are affected by human activity. Students will have opportunities to examine the causes and impacts of natural hazards and resource limitations, and they will study past, present and future climate change and its effect on humans. Additionally, students will develop scientific research skills including data collection, analysis, interpretation, and communication, through hands-on classroom activities and field experiences. The Earth Science minor complements majors in other science fields and provides an excellent foundation for any student interested in understanding the world around them.

Requirements: Students intending to major in economics should declare their major as early as possible by contacting the department.
Description: Economics is the study of how people, firms, and societies allocate scarce resources. As a foundation for understanding the forces that shape individual, national, and global well-being, the study of economics cultivates a critical perspective on modern society and develops analytical skills for careers in business, government, law, and education. It also serves as excellent preparation for graduate study in a variety of disciplines, including economics, business, and law. The undergraduate program includes an introduction to microeconomics (study of individual decision makers) and macroeconomics (study of national and global economies). It also includes a core of economic theory and quantitative methods. From a broad range of electives, students can build expertise in areas like money and banking, economic development, public finance, environmental economics, and international economics. The Department of Business and Economics also offers an interdisciplinary major in international business, as well as a minor in economics, and minors in various business fields. More information about the Department of Business and Economics is available in the Departmental Profile.
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $1,000 to $7,000 per year

Description: Learn to make better decisions in life and in business with an economics minor from SUNY Brockport. You’ll be able to critically analyze business and economic situations to make informed decisions. The economics minor is open to all students, regardless of major. It can be a great complement to a variety of majors including business administration, political science, history, sociology, and more. As an economics minor, you’ll focus on the core principles of microeconomics and macroeconomics, and have the flexibility to choose advanced courses that interest you. What you'll learn: Critical thinking, Problem solving, Data analysis, Communication, Decision making.

Concentration: Creative Writing, Literature, Professional Writing, Theatre
Description: You'll delve into the history and structure of the English language, explore major literary works and traditions, and develop critical reading, writing, and research skills. The program emphasizes diverse perspectives, cultural contexts, and theoretical approaches to literature and rhetoric. You'll engage in close textual analysis, argumentative writing, and creative expression, preparing you for a wide range of career paths and graduate studies.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to full in-state tuition per year

Requirements: A minimum of 18 credits are required for the minor, at least nine of which must be taken in residence at Brockport. A minimum grade of C is required in all minor courses. The pass/fail grading option is not permitted for courses in the minor.
Description: This minor allows students to pursue their interest in English through the study of literature and writing. It provides a valuable complement to majors in many other fields such as secondary education, communication, and paralegal studies, and provides a foundation for students considering graduate study in English.

This minor helps students develop an entrepreneurial mindset, regardless of their major. You will learn how to identify opportunities, develop innovative solutions, and create value in various contexts – from starting a new business to driving innovation within an existing organization. The curriculum covers foundational principles of entrepreneurship, design thinking, business modeling, and strategic execution. Through hands-on projects and experiential learning, students will cultivate critical skills such as problem-solving, creativity, leadership, and adaptability, preparing them to thrive in a rapidly changing world.

Concentration: Earth Science, Environmental Policy and Planning, Sustainable Materials
Description: Environmental Science (BS) is a multidisciplinary program focused on understanding how Earth’s natural systems function and respond to human activities. You’ll develop an integrative approach to studying the environment and gain quantitative and analytical skills. Upon graduation, you’ll be prepared for an environmental career, graduate studies, or to contribute to community well-being as an environmentally literate citizen. Students will solve complex environmental problems through hands-on fieldwork and lab work, studying a broad array of disciplines including biology, chemistry, geology, meteorology, physics, mathematics, and computer science. They will gain real-world experience through an internship or research project, collaborate with peers and faculty on research projects in the classroom and in the field, and contribute to a more sustainable future by becoming an environmentally literate citizen.

Requirements: The Environmental Science minor is available to any student and requires a minimum of 20 credits. The minor provides a strong, interdisciplinary framework for understanding how the natural world works, how it is affected by human activity, and what we can do to protect environmental quality and create a more sustainable future for ourselves and for other species. A grade of C or higher is required for all courses to count towards the minor.
Description: Environmental Science is an interdisciplinary field that seeks to understand and address environmental challenges facing society. It integrates knowledge from natural sciences (biology, chemistry, geology, physics), social sciences (economics, sociology, political science), and humanities (ethics, philosophy) to analyze environmental problems, evaluate solutions, and promote sustainable practices. The Environmental Science minor provides students with a foundational understanding of environmental issues, scientific principles, and policy frameworks. This minor is designed to complement a wide range of majors, providing students with valuable perspectives and skills applicable to careers in environmental management, conservation, policy, and research, as well as fostering environmentally responsible citizenship.

Requirements: To declare a minor in environmental studies, students must have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.0. Minors are available to all majors except Environmental Science.
Description: The Environmental Studies Minor, housed in the Department of Environmental Science and Ecology, is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive background in environmental issues from a variety of disciplinary perspectives. Students in the minor will achieve an understanding of both the scientific principles underlying environmental problems and the social, economic, and political forces that affect them. Additionally, students will develop critical thinking skills necessary for analyzing complex environmental issues and evaluating various solutions. The minor also helps students prepare for graduate work in environmental studies or for employment in a variety of environmental fields.

The Exercise Science program at SUNY Brockport is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of human movement, exercise physiology, biomechanics, motor control, and sport and exercise psychology. This program prepares graduates for a wide range of careers in health, fitness, rehabilitation, and sports performance, as well as for advanced graduate studies in related fields. Students gain hands-on experience through laboratory work, internships, and research opportunities, applying scientific principles to improve human health and athletic performance.

Requirements: To declare a film studies minor, a student should meet with the coordinator of the Film Studies Program.
Description: The Film Studies Minor provides students with an interdisciplinary approach to the study of film. Students in the minor study film history, theory, and criticism from a variety of perspectives. The minor complements a wide range of majors by offering students the opportunity to develop critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills applicable to many fields. Courses within the minor explore film as an art form, a cultural product, and a social force, examining its historical development, theoretical frameworks, and critical methodologies. Students will learn to analyze films structurally, thematically, and contextually, engaging with diverse cinematic traditions and their impact on global cultures. The minor prepares students for further academic study in film or for careers in related fields such as media production, film archiving, journalism, and education.

Our finance major is designed to prepare students for careers in finance, economics, and business, and for graduate study in related fields. Students gain knowledge and skills in financial analysis, investment management, corporate finance, and financial markets. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in economic theory, quantitative methods, and financial modeling, preparing students to make informed financial decisions in a global business environment. Our program prepares students for various finance careers, including financial analyst, portfolio manager, risk manager, and investment banker. Students also have the opportunity to pursue industry certifications such as the CFA (Chartered Financial Analyst) and CFP (Certified Financial Planner). Our program emphasizes ethical decision-making, critical thinking, and communication skills, which are essential for success in the finance industry. Our faculty members have extensive industry experience and are dedicated to providing students with a challenging and engaging learning experience. With a strong curriculum, experienced faculty, and opportunities for career advancement, our finance major is an excellent choice for students interested in a career in finance.
Accredidation: All business programs in the School of Business and Management are accredited by AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business. AACSB accreditation is the hallmark of excellence in business education, and has been earned by less than five percent of the world's business programs.

Requirements: To declare the finance minor, students must first complete the Declaration of Major/Minor form and obtain the signature of the department chairperson. Forms are available in the department office.
Description: A finance minor will prepare you to manage wealth and gain a better understanding of financial markets, corporate finance, and investments. A finance minor is designed to complement any major, providing you with a background in financial concepts. This minor will give you a fundamental understanding of finance, making you a desirable candidate for a wide range of careers.
ScholarshipPercentage: Over 60% of incoming freshmen receive a merit-based scholarship

Description: Forensic Science is an exciting and challenging interdisciplinary major that applies science to questions of law. The Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry offers a Bachelor of Science (BS) in Forensic Science. The major is designed to meet the growing need for forensic scientists in today’s technologically advanced society. Students study the basic sciences (chemistry, biology, and physics), mathematics, and criminal justice to understand the legal system. In addition, students take specialized courses in forensic topics. Through a wide variety of courses, students develop critical thinking skills, analytical techniques, and problem-solving abilities necessary for careers in forensic science. The program includes a required internship in a forensic laboratory or similar setting, providing students with valuable practical experience. After graduation, students pursue careers as forensic scientists in crime laboratories, hospitals, and other government and private agencies, or attend graduate school in forensic science or other scientific disciplines.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $9,500 per year (Merit scholarships range from $1,000 to $9,500)

Description: The Forensic Science Minor provides students with an overview of forensic science applications. This minor requires students to complete 18 credits in forensic science and related areas. Students will develop foundational knowledge in scientific principles and analytical methods applied to criminal investigations. Coursework includes topics such as crime scene investigation, forensic analysis of evidence (e.g., biology, chemistry), and the legal context of forensic science. The minor is designed to complement a wide range of majors, including science disciplines, criminal justice, and psychology, enhancing students' career opportunities in forensic laboratories, law enforcement, and related fields. Upon completion of the Forensic Science minor, students will be able to: 1. Apply scientific principles and methods to forensic analysis. 2. Critically evaluate forensic evidence and scientific literature. 3. Communicate effectively about forensic science topics. 4. Understand the ethical and legal implications of forensic science.

Requirements: SUNY Brockport requires the following items to complete your application: A completed application (we are on the SUNY Application and the Common Application); Your official high school transcript; One letter of recommendation from a school counselor or teacher.
Description: The Geology Department offers two undergraduate degree options: the Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Geology and the Bachelor of Science (BS) in Geology. The BA degree is designed for students who want a broad background in geology but may want to combine it with another major or minor in fields such as business, communication, environmental science, secondary education, or political science. The BS degree is designed for students who plan to pursue a career in geology (e.g., environmental consultant, geologist for state or federal agencies), attend graduate school in geology, or prepare for teaching earth science at the secondary school level. Both degrees require a core of introductory and intermediate geology courses, courses in chemistry, mathematics, and physics, and a geology field camp course. The BS degree requires additional credits in geology, mathematics, and physics. Optional specializations in Geochemistry and Geophysics are available for BS Geology majors. Students interested in the BA degree are encouraged to choose a minor or second major in a complementary field of study.

This minor is designed for students who want to develop a fundamental background in geology as a secondary area of study to complement their major. The Geology Minor gives students a general understanding of the fundamental concepts of Earth materials, processes, and history. The minor is appropriate for students majoring in the physical and life sciences, environmental science, recreation, and other areas where a basic understanding of geology would be helpful.

Requirements: Formal application for admission to the major is submitted to the Department of Art after completion of the five foundation courses. In addition to the course requirements, a student must have a minimum GPA of 2.5 in all art courses attempted.
Description: Graphic designers create visual communications for diverse purposes, including websites, apps, magazines, books, packaging, environmental graphics, and branding materials. The B.F.A. in Graphic Design provides professional training with a foundation in the liberal arts. We emphasize critical thinking, creative problem-solving, and a deep understanding of design principles and practices. Our curriculum provides you with a comprehensive understanding of current practices in graphic design, including typography, branding, web design, app design, motion graphics, and publication design. You’ll develop your conceptual, aesthetic, and technical skills through hands-on projects, studio critiques, and professional practice experiences. We also emphasize the importance of critical thinking, research, and effective communication, preparing you to become a well-rounded and adaptable designer.

A minor in graphic design provides students with foundational skills and conceptual understanding in various aspects of graphic design. This minor is open to all students.
